vclaim: "Someone in the Obama system has decided to get rid of" the issue of citizenship in the census.
date: stated on July 12, 2019 in a "Fox & Friends" appearance:
title: Limbo blames Obama for not asking for citizenship.
text: The day after President Donald Trump cancelled his bid to add a question to the 2020 census asking about the status of American citizenship, Radio host Rush Limbo struck Democrats against the question. "The real difference here is, who took the citizenship issue from the census, and why?" Lembo said during his appearance on "Fox Friends." "It seems to me that this kind of concern should have been asked when someone in Obama decided to get rid of it." However, Limbo was twisting the facts, because the issue of nationality did not disappear entirely under the leadership of former President Barack Obama. This is what our government partners identified in Politi Vact North Carolina when they investigated a similar allegation from Rep. Mark Medows, R-N.C., in April. Some things have changed since then. The Supreme Court rejected the reason given by the Trump administration for including the issue of citizenship in June. On 11 July, Trump ordered all federal agencies to hand over to the Department of Commerce any information on the number of non-citizens in the United States. Unless the history of citizenship in the census changes. The census has been conducted every decade since 1790 to obtain a national population used to determine the distribution of seats in Congress. A question about citizenship first appeared in the population census in 1820 and again in 1830, according to the United States Census Bureau. In 1870, a question was asked about males aged 21 and over, which appeared in some form as a question for all respondents every decade since 1890, with the exception of 1960. But the last time the Census Bureau asked every family about citizenship was in 1950, when census workers wrote doorways where everyone was born and asked, "If a foreigner is born - is he naturalized?" After 1950, the 1960 census inquired about the place of birth but not about nationality. Since 1970, the Census Office began to distribute two different questionnaires: a short form sent to most families, and a long form sent to only about one in six households. It is important that only the long form was asked about nationality, which means that a sample of households actually saw a question of nationality every time the census was conducted between 1970 and 2000. What did Obama change? The 2010 census was the first to take place under Obama ' s supervision, giving up the long form, using only a short questionnaire of 10 questions not asked about citizenship. However, this does not mean that the Obama administration has abolished the issue of citizenship. By 2010, the Census Bureau was already asking about citizenship through the American Community Survey, an annual survey launched in 2005 benefiting some 3.5 million households each year as a means of collecting demographic and socio-economic information on an ongoing basis. The Lembo claim that "someone in the Obama system has decided to get rid of it" is misleading, as the Obama Census Bureau has asked about citizenship through the Association of Caribbean States, which has already replaced the long-term census sent by the survey to a sample of households. For information, the Association raises the issue of citizenship every year since 2010 as well. "Someone in Obama's system decided to get rid of" said Lembo, our governor. No question of citizenship has been asked about all households in the United States since 1950. Between 1970 and 2000, the question was limited to the Long Census Questionnaire, which included only one in six households. In 2010, the Obama administration completed the entire long version.
